file.title: HTML Elements
file.bullet: HTML uses elements to describe the data in a web document. These elements help give meaning and context to information being displayed.

With the exception of void elements, all elements begin with an opening tag that is the name of the element inside of angle brackets (|||lt and >) and end with a closing tag, which is the name of the element preceded by a /, also inside of angle brackets.
In between the opening and closing tag is the contents of the element. This can be either text, or additional html elements.
When an element contains other elements, we say that the surrounding element is the parent element, and the nested elements are the child elements.
There are three basic type of elements; block-level, inline, and void.
In HTML programming, a block-level element is any element that starts a new line, like a paragraph, and uses the full width of the page or container.
A block-level element is use to define a section of the page.
Block-level elements can take up one line or multiple lines and have a line break before and after the element.
Generally, block-level elements contain data, other block-level elements, or inline elements.

file.bullet: Websites often display content in multiple columns like a magazine or newspaper. Page layout is the process of placing and arranging text, images, and graphics on a web page.

HTML5 offers new semantic elements that define the different parts of a layout:
|||ltheader>. Defines a header for a document or a section.
|||ltnav>. Defines a container for navigation links.
|||ltmain>. The main content area consists of content that is directly related to the central topic of a document.
|||ltarticle>. Defines an independent self-contained article.
|||ltsection>. Defines a section in a document.
|||ltaside>. Defines content aside from the content (like a sidebar).
|||ltfooter>. Defines a footer for a document or a section.

file.bullet: What do HTML elements do?
Elements are markups that control the way the content looks on a web page. These elements help give meaning and context to information being displayed.
What are block-level elements?

In HTML programming, a block-level element is any element that starts a new line, like a paragraph, and uses the full width of the page or container. A block-level element is use to define a section of the page.
What are void elements?
Some HTML elements, are defined as "void elements". This is because they do not have a content area or a closing tag.
How are attributes set on elements?
Attributes are specified inside of the opening tag for an element, and consist of a name, an = sign, and a value inside of double quotes (""). Multiple attributes are separated by spaces.

Why is it better to use |||ltem> instead of |||lti> to italicise text?
Because using |||ltem> gives context and intent as to why the text is italicised.
What is an anchor tag used to do?
Create a hyperlink.
Why can't block-level element be placed in an inline element?
An inline element is intended to be place seamlessly in the middle of a line, but a block-level element has a line break in-front of it and behind it.
What is the |||ltmain> element use to define?
The main content area consists of content that is directly related to the central topic of a document.
What is the |||ltarticle> element use to define?
an independent self-contained article.
